author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: Rain! Sleet! Snow! The weather will do its part to dampen Americans’ celebrations.
description: The only way to celebrate New Year’s safely this year may well be to gather outside — masked, and at a safe distance from other people. But a dreary weather forecast for the next few days might make that possibility scant for much of the country.
content: The only way to celebrate New Year’s safely this year may well be to gather outside — masked, and at a safe distance from other people. But a dreary weather forecast for the next few days might make that possibility scant for much of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Recall Is Issued for Sportmix Pet Food After 28 Dogs Die
description: Midwestern Pet Foods Inc. issued the voluntary recall after tests showed that aflatoxin, which is produced by mold, exceeded acceptable levels, the F.D.A. said.
content: A pet food company is recalling several types of its Sportmix-brand dry foods for dogs and cats after 28 dogs died and eight others fell ill, possibly from ingesting fatal levels of a toxin that is produced by mold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: Working From Bed Is Actually Great
description: A perfect metaphor for a year of giving up and giving in.
content: For years, sleep experts have held one piece of common wisdom above all else: that devices have no place in the bedroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: ‘The Other Half of My Soul’: Widows of Covid-19 Bond Over Sudden Loss
description: Men have died of the coronavirus in larger numbers than women, leaving untold thousands of spouses suddenly alone. Some have turned to bereavement groups on Facebook.
content: CHICAGO — One Friday evening, Sandra McGowan-Watts, a 46-year-old doctor from suburban Chicago, opened her laptop, stifled her nerves and told strangers on a Zoom call what had happened to her husband, Steven.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur and Elsie Chen
title: A Sci-Fi Dreamer’s Poisoning Death Shocks China
description: The “billionaire millennial” Lin Qi was working with Netflix and the “Game of Thrones” creators to bring a Chinese best seller to the screen. The police have a suspect, and fans have questions.
content: He was sometimes called the “billionaire millennial,” and his ambitions were no less grand than his nickname.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Winter TV Preview: 21 Shows to Watch
description: Newcomers and old favorites include a Marvel series, the long-awaited return of “Gomorrah” and Judi Dench among the orangutans.
content: After a historically awful year, you can take it as either bewildering or reassuring that television steams ahead on a mostly steady course, providing familiar entertainment amid the vast disruptions of politics and the pandemic. This chronological listing of programs to look forward to in the first two months of 2021 includes a blend, comfortingly or distressingly recognizable, of new shows and old favorites (and a major new streaming service, Discovery+).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Samuel Little, Serial Killer Who Confessed to 93 Murders, Dies at 80
description: At least 50 of those murders were verified by law enforcement officers, according to the F.B.I., which declared Mr. Little the “most prolific” serial killer in U.S. history.
content: Samuel Little, who surpassed even such lethal predators as Ted Bundy and John Wayne Gacy to become the most prolific serial killer in U.S. history while going undetected for decades, died at a Los Angeles-area hospital on Wednesday, California corrections officials said. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson D. Schwartz
title: Unemployment Claims Remain High as Millions Still Struggle to Find Work
description: Applications dipped slightly during Christmas week but at around 800,000 are well above historical levels.
content: More than nine months after the Covid-19 virus started spreading widely, the economy remains stuck in the state that characterized it for much of 2020. While many big businesses are prospering, the service economy is constrained by restrictions and a wariness to spend in many parts of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dylan Loeb McClain
title: Klara Kasparova, Mother of Chess Champion and His Guide, Dies at 83
description: She was an important force behind his success, and he called her practically every day, no matter where he was in the world. She died of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: Vaccines Take a While to Kick In. Experts Say That Means the Body Is Doing Its Job.
description: Reports of Covid-19 cases that appeared shortly after a single shot of a two-dose vaccine shouldn’t cause concern.
content: A flurry of headlines this week flooded social media, documenting a seemingly concerning case of Covid-19 in a San Diego nurse who fell ill about a week after receiving his first injection of Pfizer’s coronavirus vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: N.F.L. Week 17 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
description: Ten teams will be fighting for seven playoff spots on a final regular-season Sunday when numerous playoff seedings can change.
content: Heading into the final Sunday of the regular season, seven teams have secured playoff spots and 10 others are in contention for seven positions. The key battles will come in the A.FC. South and the N.F.C. East and for the wild-card spots in both conferences, with plenty of seeding yet to be decided as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Perlroth
title: Microsoft Says Russian Hackers Viewed Some of Its Source Code
description: The hackers gained more access than the company previously understood, though they were unable to modify code or get into its products and emails.
content: Microsoft said on Thursday that the far-reaching Russian hack of U.S. government agencies and private corporations had gone further into its network than the company previously understood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: Jobs, Houses and Cows: China’s Costly Drive to Erase Extreme Poverty
description: China has spent heavily to help its poorest citizens, an approach that few developing countries can afford and even Beijing may struggle to sustain.
content: JIEYUAN VILLAGE, China — When the Chinese government offered free cows to farmers in Jieyuan, villagers in the remote mountain community were skeptical. They worried officials would ask them to return the cattle later, along with any calves they managed to raise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisha Brown, Sara Aridi, Masha Goncharova and Remy Tumin
title: 10 Stories of Support in a Year of Obstacles
description: Facing challenges wrought by the pandemic, The Fund’s beneficiaries brought help to people and communities.
content: Sheeba Shafaq grew up in Afghanistan watching her grandmother work as a midwife and her father help patients as a plastic surgeon and emergency medical technician. For her, treating people was the ultimate goal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Wolfe
title: 42 people in West Virginia are mistakenly given a virus treatment instead of the vaccine.
description: Forty-two people in Boone County, in southwestern West Virginia, who were scheduled to receive the coronavirus vaccine on Wednesday were mistakenly injected with an experimental monoclonal antibody treatment instead, the West Virginia National Guard said on Thursday.
content: Forty-two people in Boone County, in southwestern West Virginia, who were scheduled to receive the coronavirus vaccine on Wednesday were mistakenly injected with an experimental monoclonal antibody treatment instead, the West Virginia National Guard said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: The Small Colorado Town felt insulated from the Pandemic. Then Came the Coronavirus Variant.
description: Simla, Colo., an isolated ranching community, is the site of the first known case in the United States of a new, more infectious variant of the coronavirus.
content: SIMLA, Colo. — An isolated ranching community on the high plains is the last place its residents expect to be first for anything, especially a new, more infectious variant of the coronavirus. But on Wednesday, state health officials announced that the first known case of the variant in the United States had been confirmed at a nursing home in Simla, Colo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: FarmVille Once Took Over Facebook. Now Everything Is FarmVille.
description: The game, a phenomenon a decade ago, is shutting down on Thursday. But its legacy — for better and for worse — carries beyond gaming.
content: In early 2009, when Facebook was still nascent in its efforts to swallow as much of the internet as possible, online games were not yet the behemoth they would become.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Powell
title: Bosses: Consider Caring a Bit
description: Workplace activism is here to stay. You might as well embrace it.
content: Hey managers, I know what you’re thinking: Now that we are getting a new president, will your employees finally pipe down?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope to Skip New Year Services Because of Painful Leg Condition
description: The Vatican said Pope Francis was suffering from sciatica, which has hobbled him in the past. But he will lead the noontime Angelus prayer on New Year’s Day.
content: ROME — The Vatican said on Thursday that Pope Francis would not be leading New Year’s Eve and New Year’s Day services in St. Peter’s Basilica because of a flare-up in a condition that causes back and leg pain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Closing of Air Traffic Control Center for Virus Cleaning Halts Flights in Dallas
description: Covid case at F.A.A. center in Fort Worth leads to ripples of delays and diverted flights across the country.
content: An air traffic control center that serves Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport was closed for several hours on Wednesday for cleaning after an employee tested positive for the coronavirus, grounding flights at one of the world’s busiest hubs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Padres Jolt M.L.B. With Bold Moves to Set Up World Series Run
description: While many teams continued to assess the financial consequences of the coronavirus pandemic, San Diego acquired two pricey pitchers and instantly became one of the favorites to win the World Series.
content: The San Diego Padres, long one of Major League Baseball’s quietest teams, jolted the sport this week. The Padres grabbed two elite pitchers, swelling the franchise’s payroll at a time of deep financial uncertainty in the game and immediately becoming a favorite to win the 2021 World Series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: MF Doom, Masked Rapper With Intricate Rhymes, Is Dead at 49
description: Born Daniel Dumile, MF Doom built a cult following with his wordplay and comic-book style. He died in October, a statement shared by his record label said.
content: Daniel Dumile, the masked rapper who performed as MF Doom and built a lasting underground fan base with his offbeat wordplay and comic-book persona, died on Oct. 31, a statement from his family said on Thursday. He was 49.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: ‘Covid Conga Line’ Aftermath: One Infected and a Suspended Liquor License
description: At least one person was hospitalized with Covid-19 after a Republican club’s party at a Queens restaurant.
content: A video of people without masks dancing in a conga line at a Republican club’s holiday party in Queens drew swift condemnation after it was posted on social media last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: How Does the Coronavirus Variant Spread? Here’s What Scientists Know
description: Contagiousness is the hallmark of the mutated virus surfacing in the U.S. and more than a dozen other countries.
content: A more contagious form of the coronavirus has begun circulating in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: News That Can Last a Million Years
description: In a year that felt apocalyptic, Martin Kunze has been making plans for the actual end of the world, with some help from The Times.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced and Marc Tracy
title: Hedge Fund Seeks Full Control of Tribune Publishing, a Major News Chain
description: Alden Global Capital, already Tribune’s biggest shareholder, is known for its practice of slashing costs in its newsrooms.
content: In the latest sign of the finance industry’s tightening grip on the local news business, Alden Global Capital has moved a significant step closer toward acquiring a major prize: Tribune Publishing, the parent of nine major metropolitan papers including The Chicago Tribune, The New York Daily News and The Baltimore Sun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Phyllis McGuire, Last of a Singing Sisters Act, Dies at 89
description: Starting in the ’50s, the McGuire Sisters were one of America’s most popular vocal groups, their three-part harmonies a balm to audiences rattled by rock ’n’ roll.
content: Phyllis McGuire, the lead singer and last surviving member of the McGuire Sisters, who bewitched teenage America in the 1950s with chart-topping renditions of “Sincerely” and “Sugartime” in a sweet, innocent harmony that went with car fins, charm bracelets and duck-tail haircuts, died on Tuesday at her home in Las Vegas. She was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Taylor
title: A pharmacist is arrested after he allegedly allowed more than 500 vaccine doses to spoil.
description: A pharmacist at a Wisconsin hospital has been arrested and accused of intentionally removing more than 500 doses of coronavirus vaccine from refrigeration last week, knowing that the vaccines would be rendered useless and that the people receiving them would think they were protected against the virus when they were not, the police department in Grafton, Wisconsin, said Thursday.
content: A pharmacist at a Wisconsin hospital has been arrested and accused of intentionally removing more than 500 doses of coronavirus vaccine from refrigeration last week, knowing that the vaccines would be rendered useless and that the people receiving them would think they were protected against the virus when they were not, the police department in Grafton, Wisconsin, said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather and Marc Stein
title: Becky Hammon Becomes First Woman to Serve as Head Coach in N.B.A. Game
description: She took over coaching the San Antonio Spurs after Gregg Popovich was ejected from a game against the Los Angeles Lakers on Wednesday night.
content: Though 2020 is nearly over, it keeps turning out sports milestones. On Wednesday night, for the first time, a woman served as head coach in an N.B.A. game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘Shadow in the Cloud’ Review: There’s Mischief in the Air
description: A World War II heroine defies death and more in this horror-action hybrid.
content: “Shadow in the Cloud” is the kind of girl-power action adventure in which women can’t just do anything, they do everything — including fighting sexist boors, enemy fire and a gremlin all at once from the underside of a bomber during World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Senator David Perdue goes into quarantine five days before Georgia’s runoff elections.
description: Senator David Perdue, Republican of Georgia, is set to quarantine, five days before a pivotal runoff election that will determine not just whether he keeps his seat but also whether Republicans maintain control of the Senate.
content: Senator David Perdue, Republican of Georgia, is set to quarantine, five days before a pivotal runoff election that will determine not just whether he keeps his seat but also whether Republicans maintain control of the Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Tanis
title: A January Menu That Comforts and Restores
description: After some heavy holiday fare, David Tanis suggests these light dishes, as impactful alone as they are together.
content: January menus, with or without resolutions, ought to be gentler and milder, given December’s inevitable excesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Some doctors in Britain plan to defy instructions to delay vaccine booster shots.
description: Some family doctors in Britain said on Thursday that they would defy the government’s instructions to postpone patients’ appointments for a second dose of coronavirus vaccine, a signal of unease in the medical community over Britain’s new plan to delay second shots as a way of giving more people the partial protection of a single dose.
content: Some family doctors in Britain said on Thursday that they would defy the government’s instructions to postpone patients’ appointments for a second dose of coronavirus vaccine, a signal of unease in the medical community over Britain’s new plan to delay second shots as a way of giving more people the partial protection of a single dose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Sasse Slams G.O.P. Effort to Challenge Election Results as a ‘Dangerous Ploy’
description: Senator Josh Hawley’s plan to object to the Electoral College votes on Jan. 6 is exposing a rift among Republicans.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Ben Sasse on Thursday condemned a drive by his Republican colleagues in Congress to challenge the results of the 2020 election, rebuking the effort as a “dangerous ploy” led by lawmakers who are “playing with fire.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: Can You Afford to Buy a Home?
description: Here’s what you need to earn in a year to get a mortgage for a median-priced home in the largest U.S. cities.
content: In this pandemic economy, homes are scarce and competition for them is fierce, meaning prices are rising even as many Americans have less money to spend. How do you know if you can afford a home in a particular city? HSH.com’s quarterly report, which breaks down the annual income required to qualify for a mortgage in the country’s 50 largest metropolitan areas, is a good starting point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danya Issawi
title: New Year’s Eve Makeup to Ring in 2021
description: Here are three ways your makeup can look fun — even in a mask.
content: In a year that has involved much isolation and solitary quality time, makeup can still be an escape from 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum and Jeremiah M. Bogert, Jr
title: New Year’s, Trump, China’s Vaccine: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Cavendish, Jamie McGee and Rick Rojas
title: Critics Say Nashville Police Could Have Done More With Tip About Bomber
description: Anthony Warner’s girlfriend told the police last year he was building bombs in his R.V. Police officials said they took their inquiry as far as they could at the time.
content: NASHVILLE — The woman was clearly in distress, sitting on her front porch with a pair of unloaded pistols beside her when the police arrived in August of last year. The weapons belonged to her boyfriend, Anthony Warner, she told the officers, and she wanted them gone. And, she added, Mr. Warner was building bombs inside the R.V. parked at his house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eleanor Stanford
title: Vanessa Kirby Has Been Waiting for a Role That Scares Her
description: For her first lead in a film, the actress wanted a character as challenging as many of those she’s played onstage. She found it in Kornel Mundruczo’s “Pieces of a Woman.”
content: LONDON — Vanessa Kirby has never given birth, but after shooting her first lead movie role in “Pieces of a Woman,” she kind of feels like she has.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Trump Was Briefed on Uncorroborated Intelligence About Chinese Bounties
description: The unverified intelligence echoes a similar report, deemed credible by the C.I.A. but dismissed by the president, that Russian military agents had offered payments for attacks on Americans in Afghanistan.
content: President Trump was briefed this month about intelligence reports that China had offered to pay bounties to fighters in Afghanistan who attacked American soldiers there, but the information was uncorroborated and comes months after Mr. Trump dismissed as a “hoax” a C.I.A. assessment that Russia had paid for such attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Chief Justice Praises the Courts’ Responses to the Pandemic
description: In a year that included an impeachment trial, the death of a colleague and the arrival of a new one, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.’s year-end report focused on the health crisis.
content: WASHINGTON — The nation’s courts have reacted nimbly to the coronavirus pandemic, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. wrote in his year-end report on the state of the federal judiciary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, HBO Max, Hulu and More in January
description: Every month, subscription streaming services add a new batch of titles to their libraries. Here are our picks for January.
content: Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our twice-weekly Watching newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Genie Chance and the Great Alaska Earthquake: An Update
description: The story of the biggest earthquake ever recorded in North America and the voice that gave Anchorage’s account in the aftermath.
content: This week, The Daily is revisiting some of our favorite episodes of the year and checking in on what has happened in the time since they first ran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: ‘Ratatouille,’ the Musical: How This TikTok Creation Came Together
description: We talked to the Broadway stars behind a virtual performance of the animated film. Inspiration started with quirky TikTok segments circulating this fall.
content: Beginning in October, thousands of TikTok creators who were bored at home and missing Broadway created elements of a show that didn’t exist yet: a musical based on Disney Pixar’s “Ratatouille,” an animated film about a rat with culinary aspirations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut, Christopher F. Schuetze, Elian Peltier, Elisabetta Povoledo, Raphael Minder, Richard Pérez-Peña and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: A locked-down Europe bids a subdued good riddance to an awful year.
description: Concerts? Canceled. Crowds and parties? Banned. Staying out all night? Don’t even think about it.
content: To ring out a year the world wishes had been an illusion, the biggest event in Paris really was one. It is called, perhaps optimistically, “Welcome to the Other Side.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins, Frances Robles and Tim Arango
title: Here’s Why Distribution of the Vaccine Is Taking Longer Than Expected
description: Health officials and hospitals are struggling with a lack of resources. Holiday staffing and saving doses for nursing homes are also contributing to delays.
content: In Florida, less than one-quarter of delivered coronavirus vaccines have been used, even as older people sat in lawn chairs all night waiting for their shots. In Puerto Rico, last week’s vaccine shipments did not arrive until the workers who would have administered them had left for the Christmas holiday. In California, doctors are worried about whether there will be enough hospital staff members to both administer vaccines and tend to the swelling number of Covid-19 patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: A beloved Chicago bowling alley gets a pandemic reprieve.
description: At first, it seemed as if Southport Lanes in the Lakeview section of Chicago would be yet another sad casualty of 2020.
content: At first, it seemed as if Southport Lanes in the Lakeview section of Chicago would be yet another sad casualty of 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Ohio offered nursing home workers early dibs on a vaccine. Many said no.
description: Although the vast majority of nursing home residents in Ohio are accepting a vaccine for Covid-19, the same cannot be said for the staff in these facilities, Gov. Mike DeWine said on Wednesday.
content: Although the vast majority of nursing home residents in Ohio are accepting a vaccine for Covid-19, the same cannot be said for the staff in these facilities, Gov. Mike DeWine said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: What Giant Skeletons and Puppy Shortages Told Us About the 2020 Economy
description: This year was awful, but it gave rise to some interesting social trends. Here’s what they tell us about the economic future.
content: Americans are divided over many things, but we can all agree that 2020 was tragic, terrifying and generally no good. Yet amid the sadness and strife, our social lives evolved rapidly and the coronavirus pandemic ushered in changes that could leave a lasting mark on the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Minneapolis Police Fatally Shoot Man During Traffic Stop
description: It was the first killing by a Minneapolis officer since George Floyd’s death in May. The chief said witnesses indicated that the man had fired first.
content: A Minneapolis police officer killed a man in an exchange of gunfire during a traffic stop on Wednesday evening, the police chief said, the first killing by a member of the department since George Floyd’s death in May. Protesters quickly descended on the snow-covered scene, and city officials begged them not to revive the unrest that left parts of the city aflame in the spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Coronavirus Dominates Merkel’s Last New Year’s Speech as Chancellor
description: An address that would usually cover a sweeping range of topics instead focuses solely on the pandemic, which has upended both Angela Merkel’s last year in office and life in Germany as whole.
content: Chancellor Angela Merkel’s New Year’s speeches have typically been aspirational exercises in political agenda setting, touching on dozens of broad themes like immigration and climate change, and sometimes presenting her latest projects for Germany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By E. Tammy Kim
title: This Is Why Nursing Homes Failed So Badly
description: The first coronavirus outbreak in the United States happened in a nursing home in February. Since then, it’s only gotten worse.
content: Eight months into the pandemic, Brendan House, a nursing home in Kalispell, Mont., had not had a single resident test positive for the coronavirus. It was an extraordinary feat, given that 40 percent of the deaths from Covid-19 nationwide had occurred in long-term care facilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Goodbye, Twitter Trump! And Other Predictions for 2021
description: The coronavirus has forced the kind of work experimentation that would have taken a decade otherwise.
content: No one expected 2020 to turn out the way it did. The worst I imagined for this year, in my annual list of digital predictions in 2019, was that the “ever screechy” President Trump would get “to stay on Twitter retweeting fake accounts and links that appear to unmask a whistle-blower.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Bristow
title: Photos From Fashion’s Uncertain Year
description: A look back at what fashion shows used to be while we wonder what's next.
content: In any other year, like clockwork, flocks of models, stylists, critics and photographers would migrate around the globe, chasing fashion shows from New York to Paris. Their usual pattern was upended in March, as coronavirus cases began to spike around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Greenhouse
title: My Joe Biden Story
description: In a career as a journalist, I had never encountered a politician like him.
content: As Ben Smith, the media columnist for The Times, suggested a few weeks ago, pretty much every journalist who passed through Washington, D.C., during the past half century knows President-elect Joe Biden and has a story to tell. I’d like to end this strange year, and welcome the new one and the new president, by telling mine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Franklin
title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Manhattan and Staten Island
description: This week’s properties are in Downtown Brooklyn, the Flatiron district and Grymes Hill.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: 2020 Taught Us How to Fix This
description: Our current model of social change isn’t working.
content: This is the year that broke the truth. This is the year when millions of Americans — and not just your political opponents — seemed impervious to evidence, willing to believe the most outlandish things if it suited their biases, and eager to develop fervid animosities based on crude stereotypes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon and Richard Fausset
title: Georgia Republicans Deliver Persistent Message: Fear the Democrats
description: Senators Kelly Loeffler and David Perdue are resting their re-election hopes on a strategy that calls more attention to what they’re against than what they support.
content: NORCROSS, Ga. — The biggest applause lines in Senator Kelly Loeffler’s stump speech are not about Ms. Loeffler at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Brexit’s Silver Lining for Europe
description: Both sides lost in Britain’s departure, but the European Union has been galvanized. And the Biden administration will encounter European allies bent on their own “strategic autonomy.”
content: PARIS — It is done at last. On Jan. 1, with the Brexit transition period over, Britain will no longer be part of the European Union’s single market and customs union. The departure will be ordered, thanks to a last-minute deal running to more than 1,200 pages, but still painful to both sides. A great loss will be consummated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meghan O'Gieblyn
title: In Searching Essays, Knausgaard Extols the Freedom and Limitations of Art
description: “In the Land of the Cyclops,” the Norwegian author’s first essay collection to be published in English, circles the mysteries of artistic creation, including his own writing process.
content: IN THE LAND OF THE CYCLOPSEssaysBy Karl Ove Knausgaard
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hillary Richard
title: Booze Fairies Flit Across America
description: Neighbors have been donning wings and tutus to deliver adult beverages and other goodies.
content: Savannah Dana, 26, was mentally congratulating herself for sneaking into a gated community around Nashville when she noticed blue flashing lights in her rearview mirror.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: The vote on a long-awaited Brexit deal.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: A Brief History of 2020 in California, in Photos
description: Thursday: Looking back on images of the year.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: New in Paperback: ‘The Red Lotus’ and ‘This Is Big’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: THE TRUANTS, by Kate Weinberg. (Putnam, 336 pp., $17.) This “hypnotic,” “uncommonly clever” debut whodunit, our crime columnist, Marilyn Stasio, declared, “might have met with the approval of the Queen of Crime, Agatha Christie,” to whose books, plot twists, settings and life its author “makes plentiful references ... all while coming across as madly original.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Stunned by their husbands’ sudden deaths, widows of Covid-19 forge ties.
description: More than 340,000 people have died of the coronavirus in the United States. Men have died of the disease in larger numbers than women, which has left untold thousands of spouses suddenly widowed by the virus.
content: More than 340,000 people have died of the coronavirus in the United States. Men have died of the disease in larger numbers than women, which has left untold thousands of spouses suddenly widowed by the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Happy New Year. Have you read any Sylvia Plath lately? Daphne Merkin’s excellent review of a new Plath biography (“Red Comet,” by Heather Clark) sent me back to her early poem “The Beekeeper’s Daughter,” a wonderfully fecund portrait of nature at its most Freudian — all sex and death, as nature tends to be — and from there to “Ariel,” with its unbeatable sequence of bee poems and daddy issues. You should read those this week, then read Clark’s biography for a fuller sense of the tumultuous life and mind behind the work. And if you’re hungry for more poetry, we also recommend the collection “That Was Now, This Is Then,” by the Pulitzer winner Vijay Seshadri. No bees there — but there are “birds fretting at the feeder.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard A. Friedman
title: 2020 Was a Test. How Did We Do?
description: The pandemic gave us an unwelcome chance to find out what we missed, what we could do without — and how much risk we are willing to take.
content: You don’t need a psychiatrist to tell you it’s been a brutal year. But looking back on 2020, it’s clear we’ve undergone a big psychosocial stress test: Our response to the deadly challenge of Covid-19 helped us discover what we value and who we really are, a mirror held up to humanity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: Was That a Dropped Call From ET?
description: A spooky radio signal showed up after a radio telescope was aimed at the next star over from our sun.
content: Nobody believes it was ET phoning, but radio astronomers admit they don’t have an explanation yet for a beam of radio waves that apparently came from the direction of the star Proxima Centauri.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: U.S. Companies to Face China Tariffs as Exclusions Expire
description: Many American companies could see their exemptions from President Trump’s China tariffs expire at midnight on Thursday.
content: WASHINGTON — American companies are facing the prospect of higher taxes on some of the products they import from China, as the tariff exclusions that had shielded many businesses from President Trump’s trade war are set to expire at midnight on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Missouri Senator Says He’ll Join Election Challenge, Dividing the G.O.P.
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, December 31, 2020.
content: “This is a very serious person doing a very unserious thing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Seriously? He Gets an Early Vaccine?
description: My sister’s Covid-downplaying politician husband is even more insufferable now that he’s been vaccinated. How do I talk to her about him?
content: Many years ago, my sister married a young politician whose views are very different from hers and mine. I talked to her about it; she said they were good at compartmentalizing. Over time, his positions grew worse. He spent last year, for instance, downplaying Covid-19 and ignoring safety precautions. (I don’t know what compartment my sister put that in!) Now I’ve learned he took a Covid vaccine when legislators were offered them. He is not a health care worker, elderly or at risk. People could die because of his selfishness! How can I talk to my sister about this? I love her, but I can’t take it anymore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Motavalli
title: Look but Don’t Touch: Supercars That Have Barely Been Driven
description: The power and prestige of cars like a 1990 Lamborghini might compel some owners to take a Sunday drive. But with odometers this low, the investment would take a hit.
content: Supercars hold their value better the less you play with them, much like collectible children’s toys that are worth more when sealed inside the original packaging. But what’s the fun in that?
source.name: The New York Times

title: In the Cultural Revolution, Ai Weiwei’s Father Burned the Family’s Books
description: “It confirmed in me how powerful those words printed on paper, and the images in between, could be.”
content: “It confirmed in me how powerful those words printed on paper, and the images in between, could be,” says the artist and human rights activist, whose new book is “Human Flow: Stories From the Global Refugee Crisis.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: German Automakers Are Charged Up and Ready to Take on Tesla
description: As Tesla completes a factory in Berlin, Mercedes-Benz and Audi are introducing electric cars in bids to defend their dominance of the luxury market.
content: HOCKENHEIM, Germany — The Porsche Taycan rocketed from a standstill so fast that my skull banged against the headrest and my vision went blurry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Brexit, Finalized
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: More than four years after Britain voted to leave the European Union, new travel and trade rules will go into effect tomorrow, concluding a saga that has divided Britons and dominated British politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: An Olympic Dream Is Reborn, Despite Fears of Brain Trauma
description: A.J. Edelman walked away from the hazards of sledding sports after he competed for Israel in the skeleton at the 2018 Winter Games. Now he is trying again in a bobsled.
content: A.J. Edelman was worried.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: 5 Anchorwomen to Leave NY1 After Settling Discrimination Suit
description: Roma Torre, a signature presence at the New York City cable news channel, is among the group of women who are departing.
content: Five NY1 anchorwomen, including the longtime New York City television personality Roma Torre, are leaving the local news channel after settling an age and gender discrimination lawsuit against the beloved media institution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Rattner and Lalena Fisher
title: The Year in Charts
description: A tour of the major trends, from Covid-19 spread to political polarization, that affected Americans this year.
content: If 2019 was the Year of Trump, then 2020 was the Year of Covid-19 and Trump. Only the most devastating pandemic in a century could have bumped our loudmouthed president into second place. That is, until Joe Biden also took him down a peg, in a free and fair election with an unambiguous result — except in the world of Trump. And oh yes, all of this occurred during the biggest recession since the Great Depression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Maggie Haberman, Noah Weiland, Sharon LaFraniere and Mark Mazzetti
title: Trump’s Focus as the Pandemic Raged: What Would It Mean for Him?
description: President Trump missed his chance to show that he could rise to the moment in the final chapter of his presidency and meet the defining challenge of his tenure.
content: WASHINGTON — It was a warm summer Wednesday, Election Day was looming and President Trump was even angrier than usual at the relentless focus on the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: This Is Why You Heard About TikTok So Much in 2020
description: Business, entertainment, news, activism and social connection will never be the same.
content: It’s been well over two years since TikTok arrived in the United States in August 2018, offering a rejoinder to anyone who thought social media had lost its way. The app had everything: social commentary, comedy, crafting, memes, challenges, makeup tutorials and, of course, dances. Even those who weren’t totally sold on it couldn’t avoid the videos, which proliferated across platforms like Instagram, YouTube and Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Gibraltar Gets Its Own Last-Minute Brexit Deal on Borders
description: Spain and the European Union will share oversight over the flow of goods and people to the British territory, which worried about being left isolated and economically pinched outside the bloc.
content: MADRID — The recent Brexit trade deal generated relief in Britain and the European Union, but some issues were left on the negotiating table — including what to do about Gibraltar, the British territory at the southern tip of Spain whose sovereignty has long been disputed by Madrid.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 11 Things Our Critics Are Looking Forward to in 2021
description: Nicolas Cage hosts the history of swearing. Lorde writes a book and Julie Mehretu takes over the Whitney. This new year has to be better, right?
content: As a new year begins, our critics highlight the TV, movies, music, art and streaming dance and theater they anticipate before summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Australia Tweaks Anthem to Recognize Indigenous History
description: The words “we are young and free” were changed to “we are one and free.” The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have lived on the continent for more than 60,000 years.
content: The lyrics of Australia’s national anthem have been altered by one word to recognize the country’s Indigenous history, Prime Minister Scott Morrison announced Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: ‘Not everyone is at the New Year’s table now’: Putin laments the virus’s grip on Russia.
description: With parks, ice-rinks, bars and other popular venues for New Year’s Eve in Moscow ordered to shut down before midnight on Thursday because of the coronavirus pandemic, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia kept one holiday tradition alive by delivering a televised address to the nation.
content: With parks, ice-rinks, bars and other popular venues for New Year’s Eve in Moscow ordered to shut down before midnight on Thursday because of the coronavirus pandemic, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia kept one holiday tradition alive by delivering a televised address to the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Sorel
title: That Time When Theodore Dreiser Slapped Sinclair Lewis in the Face
description: At a 1931 banquet at the Metropolitan Club, two literary giants clashed over plagiarism and bruised egos.
content: Both grew up in the Midwest, both wrote novels that skewered the patriarchal, conformist towns where they were raised, and both shared the distinction of having churchmen condemn their books as “immoral.” They should have been friends, but by 1925, when Theodore Dreiser’s “An American Tragedy” was published, he and Sinclair Lewis were hoping to become the first American to win the Nobel Prize in Literature. Lewis had already produced “Main Street” in 1920, then followed it with “Babbitt,” “Arrowsmith,” “Elmer Gantry” and “Dodsworth” before the decade was even over. In 1930 the prize was his.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Some recipe ideas for a New Year’s Eve at home.
description: Make yourself a Grown-Up Granita. For dinner, may we suggest Steak au Poivre. And for New Year’s Day, some green juice might help.
content: Whether you’re ringing in the new year with Champagne and caviar or with a lucky plate of black-eyed peas and greens, the Cooking staff at The Times has compiled recipe ideas for a celebration at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Happy Face’ Review: Alternative Therapy
description: In Alexandre Franchi’s film, a 19-year-old crashes a support group and leads its members to personal breakthroughs.
content: A defiant, generically unclassifiable film that dares viewers to question its sensitivity, “Happy Face” centers on a 19-year-old named Stan (Robin L’Houmeau) who wraps gauze around his head and joins a support group for people with atypical facial appearances. When the assertiveness exercises proposed by the group’s leader, Vanessa (Debbie Lynch-White), don’t do much good, Stan takes command, illustrating for his new friends that cognitive behavioral therapy isn’t nearly as cathartic as dumping trash on gawking restaurant patrons. Stan’s vision for the cohort is a cross between a pushy version of the talking cure and a fight club.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Hua
title: The Champagne Toast Takes on Extra Special Meaning
description: When my parents first met the man who would become my husband, they ordered a bottle of Piper-Heidsieck and waited for news of a proposal.
content: When my father ordered champagne, it baffled my boyfriend, but not me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Laetitia Vancon
title: A German Town Warily Considers a Future Without a Deep U.S. Presence
description: American culture, friends and jobs are part of the fabric of Vilseck, home to a U.S. military base. President Trump has forced its people to think about what it would mean to lose that.
content: VILSECK, Germany — There is a bar here called “Cheers,” and there are Halloween parties, decorated houses and trick-or-treating in October and turkeys at Thanksgiving. The mayor’s childhood memories include Hershey’s bars, jars of peanut butter and Wrigley’s gum.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do This New Year’s Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually.
content: Since September, the Joyce Theater has been offering a free virtual fall season that is as good as some of its best in-person ones. The secret has been surprise and an avoidance of the usual suspects. If that is a little less true of the latest batch of videos — available through Sunday at joyce.org/joycestream — the variety still provides plenty of spice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nellie Bowles
title: Daniel M. Tellep, Engineer Who Steered Lockheed’s Growth, Dies at 89
description: A pioneer of aerospace and missile systems, he rose to chief executive, then initiated the Lockheed-Martin merger that formed the world’s largest military contractor.
content: Daniel M. Tellep, an aerospace engineer who initiated a merger between Lockheed and Martin Marietta to form the world’s largest military contractor, then became its first chief executive, died on Nov. 26 at his home in Saratoga, Calif. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: Alexander Wang, Accused of Sexual Assault, Denies Allegations
description: “I never engaged in the atrocious behavior described,” Mr. Wang said, after a model alleged he was groped by Mr. Wang, setting off a wave of accusations against the fashion designer.
content: This week, Owen Mooney, a male model and graphic designer, said that he was groped by Alexander Wang, an influential fashion designer, in a New York City nightclub in 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Stapinski
title: Superheroes and Trailblazers: Black Comic Book Artists, Rediscovered
description: A new book examines the lives of these trailblazers, who paved the way for subsequent generations of illustrators but were invisible to the mainstream in their own time.
content: Ken Quattro’s deep dive into Black comic book artists started out of frustration. Twenty years ago, while researching a man named Matt Baker whose drawings were distinguished by his strong style, Mr. Quattro, a comics fan and blogger, kept coming up empty-handed. “There was nothing about him except that he was Black and that he died young,” said Mr. Quattro, who is known as the Comics Detective.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Most Popular Real Estate Stories of 2020
description: Many of our most-read articles this year sprang from the coronavirus pandemic, whether examining its impact or offering ideas for diversion.
content: As with every other aspect of American life in 2020, the coronavirus pandemic dominated the real estate industry this year — wreaking havoc on markets, shattering our ingrained routines and traditions at home, changing the way we move around, and leaving us with an uneasy awareness that 2021 may be equally unpredictable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claudia Gryvatz Copquin and Lisa Prevost
title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom in Great Neck, N.Y., and a three-bedroom in Fairfield, Conn.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: Fou Ts’ong, Pianist Whose Family Letters Inspired a Generation, Dies at 86
description: Driven from China during Mao’s rule, Mr. Fou kept up a correspondence with his father that became a beloved book in the wake of the Cultural Revolution.
content: Fou Ts’ong, a Chinese-born pianist known for his sensitive interpretations of Chopin, Debussy and Mozart, and whose letters from his father, a noted translator and writer, influenced a generation of Chinese readers, died on Monday at a hospital in London, where he had lived for many years. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Wise
title: Joy survives: Readers share memories of the good moments from this year.
description: Even in this dark year, there have been moments of lightness, growth and utter joy.
content: Even in this dark year, there have been moments of lightness, growth and utter joy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: ‘No Realistic Path’ for Quick Vote on $2,000 Stimulus Checks, McConnell Says
description: The Senate leader all but ended any chance of increasing direct payments, despite some Republican support for the effort.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell effectively killed off any chance that Congress would increase stimulus checks to $2,000 before President Trump leaves office, saying there was “no realistic path” for the Senate to pass a stand-alone bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry
title: Preparing for a new year, many have a message for the old one: good riddance.
description: Last New Year’s Eve, a million strong crowd flooded Midtown Manhattan, kissing and cheering in the warm glow of 2020’s promise. This New Year’s Eve, just a few hundred will gather in Times Square — dozens of frontline workers among them — and only then by special invitation.
content: Last New Year’s Eve, a million strong crowd flooded Midtown Manhattan, kissing and cheering in the warm glow of 2020’s promise. This New Year’s Eve, just a few hundred will gather in Times Square — dozens of frontline workers among them — and only then by special invitation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Virus Disrupts College Football Playoffs Even Before Kickoff
description: Both semifinals are being played in abnormal circumstances: The Rose Bowl will be in Texas, and the Sugar Bowl will feature teams hit hard by the coronavirus.
content: The Sun Bowl, which has been played in El Paso, Texas, every year since 1935, is such a local institution that its organizers were determined to play the game even if teams arrived the day before the New Year’s Eve kickoff and attendance had to be capped at 8,600.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Alexandra E. Petri
title: Here’s how New York City is planning to break up illicit parties.
description: The New York City Sheriff’s Office, which has been the city’s primary agency enforcing coronavirus-related restrictions at bars and restaurants, will have additional deputies working on New Year’s Eve to monitor and break up any illicit parties, the sheriff, Joe Fucito, said on Wednesday.
content: The New York City Sheriff’s Office, which has been the city’s primary agency enforcing coronavirus-related restrictions at bars and restaurants, will have additional deputies working on New Year’s Eve to monitor and break up any illicit parties, the sheriff, Joe Fucito, said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilana Kaplan
title: Fuzzy Slippers for a Frazzled Year
description: You should absolutely be wearing shoes at home. Why not make them as cloudlike as possible?
content: Once upon a time, slippers were reserved for the hours spent indoors before and after work. But for the masses working from home this year, dress codes have been transformed — business casual, who? — including footwear. Farewell, heels; hello, fuzzy slides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: Jimmy Lai, Hong Kong Pro-Democracy Mogul, Is Ordered Back to Jail
description: Mr. Lai, the most prominent figure charged under Hong Kong’s sweeping national security law, had been released on bail just days before Thursday’s hearing.
content: HONG KONG — Hong Kong’s highest court ordered Jimmy Lai, the pro-democracy publishing tycoon, back to jail on Thursday, just days after he was freed on bail, the latest twist in the continuing, flip-flopping legal battle over one of the city’s most prominent antigovernment figures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Confetti falls on a deserted Times Square as New York forges ahead.
description: In the lead-up to the evening, officials warned New Yorkers and tourists that all uninvited guests would be turned away.
content: The minute before midnight in Times Square was almost unrecognizable as New York City closed out one of the most difficult and wrenching years in its history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Times Square will be closed off, but the ball drop is happening.
description: This year, for the first time in decades, Times Square will be closed to the public on New Year’s Eve. Only production workers and dozens of selected frontline workers and their families will be permitted near the stage.
content: This year, for the first time in decades, Times Square will be closed to the public on New Year’s Eve. Only production workers and dozens of selected frontline workers and their families will be permitted near the stage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Diego Salazar
title: The Year of Not Eating Out
description: When dining is your community, losing restaurants is about more than food.
content: MEXICO CITY — A couple of weeks ago my wife and I did something we hadn’t done in a year: We had late-night tacos from our favorite street taco stand, Los Juanes. It’s a small neighborhood-famous stand, run by three young men and an older guy named Juan, on a poorly illuminated corner three blocks from our apartment. I found it when we first moved to Mexico City from Lima, Peru, in early 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: The Bomb That Struck the Heart of Nashville
description: I’m thinking of the weight we’ve all been carrying this year, in my city and everywhere else.
content: NASHVILLE — If years were musical genres, 2020 would be a country song — or maybe a blues album, or possibly gospel. It’s hard to know, in the midst of sorrow, exactly which brand of anguish is lodged in the human soul. I do know this, though: It’s been a miserable year here, a year that tore our hearts to pieces even before a bomb reduced a historic part of this city to rubble on Christmas Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: Seeing Color: A Matter of Nature, or Culture?
description: An exhibition at the Museum of Natural History is the sum of all lessons on hue.
content: The days have turned gray, the future feels black. We’re all seeing red, we’re all feeling blue. Perhaps it’s the isolated colors that are bringing us down; perhaps what we need is a whole spectrum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Their Finances Ravaged, Customers Fear Banks Will Withhold Stimulus Checks
description: Banks have the power to decide whether to let overdrawn customers gain access to the stimulus money being deposited into their accounts, but they have taken different approaches.
content: Since August, Morgan Banke has had just enough money in her bank account every month to pay either her rent or her car insurance. The unemployed mother of two has relied on her bank, the Dupaco Community Credit Union in Dubuque, Iowa, to cover the difference. But each time she makes that choice, the bank charges her $28 in overdraft fees. Her account is $780 in the red.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: India imposes a curfew in New Delhi to curb New Year celebrations.
description: The authorities in India are imposing a night curfew in the capital, New Delhi, restricting celebrations in a metropolis known for hosting grand events on New Year’s Eve after more cases of a new variant of coronavirus were reported across the country.
content: The authorities in India are imposing a night curfew in the capital, New Delhi, restricting celebrations in a metropolis known for hosting grand events on New Year’s Eve after more cases of a new variant of coronavirus were reported across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Joe Orovic
title: Hundreds of Migrants Stranded in Freezing Weather in Bosnia
description: Up to 700 people lacking winter clothes, sleeping bags and tents have slept outside after a temporary camp was dismantled. Local hostility has blocked efforts to relocate them.
content: Hundreds of migrants stranded at an abandoned camp in Bosnia and Herzegovina were spending New Year’s Eve in freezing temperatures, according to humanitarian groups, as authorities in the country struggled to balance their safety with growing hostility from local populations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Largely free of the virus, New Zealand could party like it was 2019.
description: With the threat of the pandemic all but banished from its shores, New Zealand approached the holiday season much as it ordinarily does.
content: By 11 a.m. on New Year’s Eve, the supply of craft ale at liquor stores in the popular beach town of Raglan was already somewhat depleted, as throngs of New Zealanders prepared to be among the first to bid farewell to a thoroughly unusual year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Austyn Gaffney
title: After Breonna Taylor Case, Louisville Police Face Precarious Next Chapter
description: An interim police chief has nearly finished her work, and the city is at a crossroads. Will a department handling one of the nation’s most controversial police shootings win back the city’s trust?
content: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — The news conference on a Friday afternoon in March was brief and opaque. The Louisville police chief said officers serving a drug warrant at an apartment had been met with gunfire. An officer had been shot and a woman had been killed, the chief said, and a man inside had been charged with trying to murder a police officer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: We Came All This Way to Let Vaccines Go Bad in the Freezer?
description: America did not sufficiently plan for how to get millions of people vaccinated.
content: It’s been two weeks since U.S. officials launched what ought to be the largest vaccination campaign in the nation’s history. So far, things are going poorly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Wise
title: Joy Survives: Your Positive Moments From 2020
description: Readers share memories of the good moments from this year, and reflect on what they mean now.
content: The coronavirus pandemic has killed more than 1.3 million people around the world. Millions more have lost their jobs, and governments have offered uneven support. In the United States, a reckoning with race and discrimination poured into the streets during the summer, and its effects have rippled into the fall. The country’s presidential election brought record-breaking turnout but led to a debate over the very essence of the democratic process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Taylor
title: A holiday all about drinking and reveling with mobs of strangers — what could go wrong?
description: First there was Thanksgiving, when some families who gathered for turkey and stuffing also shared the coronavirus, causing cases to spike in some places and further taxing the nation’s already stretched hospitals.
content: First there was Thanksgiving, when some families who gathered for turkey and stuffing also shared the coronavirus, causing cases to spike in some places and further taxing the nation’s already stretched hospitals.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 10 Classical Concerts to Stream in January
description: A Verdi opera from the Met and composers on the border of classical and pop are among the highlights.
content: As the live performing arts still reel from the coronavirus pandemic, here are 10 highlights from the flood of online music content coming in January. (Times listed are Eastern.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Williams
title: How Politics, Protests and the Pandemic Shaped a Year in Books
description: From “American Dirt” to “Apropos of Nothing” to “A Promised Land,” here is what happened in the literary and publishing world’s unforgettable 2020.
content: The year in books, like the year everywhere else, was a simultaneously breakneck and slow-motion mixture of exhaustion, peril, controversy, inspiration and resilience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross and Marie Fazio
title: Here are some ways you can see off the year, virtually.
description: How to commemorate the end of a year of widespread unemployment, racial unrest and political animosity, not to mention an ongoing pandemic? If you’re at home looking for a festive yet socially distanced way to bid farewell to 2020, consider taking a virtual trip around the world.
content: How to commemorate the end of a year of widespread unemployment, racial unrest and political animosity, not to mention an ongoing pandemic? If you’re at home looking for a festive yet socially distanced way to bid farewell to 2020, consider taking a virtual trip around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Richard Thornburgh, Former Governor and Attorney General, Dies at 88
description: He steered Pennsylvania through the Three Mile Island nuclear plant meltdown and led the Justice Department under Reagan and the first President Bush.
content: Dick Thornburgh, a two-term Republican governor of Pennsylvania who coped with America’s worst nuclear power meltdown at Three Mile Island in 1979 and later served as United States attorney general under Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush, died on Thursday at a retirement home in Oakmont, Pa., outside Pittsburgh. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian Friedman
title: Once a Fringe Idea, the $15 Minimum Wage Is Making Big Gains
description: The new year brings another round of increases, nearly a decade after workers started campaigning for higher pay.
content: It started in 2012 with a group of protesters outside a McDonald’s demanding a $15 minimum wage — an idea that even many liberal lawmakers considered outlandish. In the years since, their fight has gained traction across the country, including in conservative states with low union membership and generally weak labor laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen T. Verongos
title: Squirming, Maybe
description: David J. Kahn escorts the old year to the door.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — This is the final Wordplay of the year, and what a year it has been for crosswords, which were surely one of the amusements that kept us sane. To celebrate, we invited David J. Kahn into our living room for the most entertaining solving session of the week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: This Police Union Suspended 8 Members. Seven Are Black.
description: The union in a small New Jersey city punished the officers after they expressed support for two chiefs, both of whom are also Black.
content: ENGLEWOOD, N.J. — The tensions within the Englewood Police Department had simmered for months: at disciplinary hearings, during Black Lives Matter marches and in the fallout over no-confidence votes by the officers’ union in the chief and deputy chief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Shaw
title: Louis Kahn-Designed Dorms in India May Be Razed
description: Plans to demolish part of a Kahn project at the Indian Institute of Management in Ahmedabad are drawing objections from preservationists, like the World Monuments Fund.
content: A world-class architectural-preservation controversy is brewing in India, where the administration at the Indian Institute of Management in Ahmedabad had announced plans to raze 14 of 18 student dormitory buildings designed by the architect Louis Kahn and built in the 1960s and 1970s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg
title: How 11 Kids Think the Biden Administration Should Spend Our Money
description: Vaccines, global warming, kid-sized chairs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Gay
title: What It Takes to Heal From Covid-19
description: Survivors can get better, but they need help.
content: I am one of millions of people still fighting to regain their full health months after surviving Covid-19. But this is not a story about sickness. This is a story about the small army of people who are helping me heal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: When the virus variant came to a tiny Colorado town.
description: Simla, Colo., an isolated ranching community on the high plains, is the last place locals expect to be first for anything, especially a new, more infectious variant of the coronavirus.
content: Simla, Colo., an isolated ranching community on the high plains, is the last place locals expect to be first for anything, especially a new, more infectious variant of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: In Minority Communities, Doctors Are Changing Minds About Vaccination
description: Many Black and Hispanic Americans mistrust government officials, and instead have turned to physicians they have long known.
content: Like many Black and rural Americans, Denese Rankin, a 55-year-old retired bookkeeper and receptionist in Castleberry, Ala., did not want the Covid-19 vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: This Is How New Yorkers Will Remember a Year They Can’t Wait to Forget
description: “There’s some pieces of normalcy that I don’t really want back,” said one New Yorker. “Our normal wasn’t always ideal.”
content: New Yorkers stand this week as the living footnotes of tomorrow’s textbooks. The year 2020 will be studied by historians, scientists and schoolchildren for generations, and yet, it will be known by many of those who lived through it for the singular moments that arrived behind a pandemic’s deadly waves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Two Ways Home’ Review: A Spare Family Drama Unfolds in Iowa
description: Cast with mostly unknown actors, the film follows a woman who strains to connect with her daughter after being released from prison.
content: The family drama “Two Ways Home” opens with a whirlwind prologue, finding its heroine in a crisis of her own making. Kathy, played by Tanna Frederick, is holding up a convenience store, brashly shouting instructions to the baffled cashier before she’s caught by the police. In prison, she learns she has bipolar disorder and, after achieving some stability, is released early on good behavior. Now all she has to do is make sense of the mess she left behind at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: This year, the midnight drag queen arrives at 9 p.m.
description: For 23 years, the New Year’s Eve tradition in Key West has been a drag queen descending from an eight-foot red stiletto at the stroke of midnight.
content: Joe Schroeder, a bar owner in Key West, Fla., faced a dilemma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Nicole Brown
title: Yup, People Are Going to Parties on New Year’s Eve
description: Not-so-secret nightclubs in Los Angeles and new apps alike seek partygoers, even as the coronavirus pandemic rattles California.
content: Prohibition in the United States, a short-lived experiment that began 100 years ago, popularized the speakeasy: an illicit establishment designed to sell alcoholic beverages during the years they were legally banned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Should Wine Be Among Your Health Resolutions?
description: The new category of ‘clean wines’ is an effort to appeal to those seeking wellness. But why try to rationalize wine as a healthful product?
content: As is customary for the new year, many people will vow to change their ways and pledge to improve their health. Chief among their concerns will be wine and other alcoholic beverages. Dry Januarys have become fashionable, as has what has come to be called the new sobriety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kalyn Kahler
title: Randall Cunningham Is Back in the N.F.L. … as Raiders Chaplain
description: “I want to preach myself into a Super Bowl ring.”
content: Despite his best efforts, Randall Cunningham just can’t retire from football. A former quarterback for the Philadelphia Eagles and Minnesota Vikings, he tried walking away from the game twice, dabbling in a variety of activities to fill the void.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josie Moyer
title: Guam quietly leads the United States into 2021.
description: The first populated area of the United States to escape 2020 did so at 9 a.m. Eastern in subdued fashion. Bars and nightclubs were closed in Guam, a U.S. territory that sits between Japan and Australia, and fireworks shows were canceled.
content: The first populated area of the United States to escape 2020 did so at 9 a.m. Eastern in subdued fashion. Bars and nightclubs were closed in Guam, a U.S. territory that sits between Japan and Australia, and fireworks shows were canceled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: “Cobra Kai” returns in fighting form this long holiday weekend, or you can ring in 2021 with a quirky new comedy from some of the creative team behind “Bob’s Burgers.”
content: Every Monday and Friday, Margaret offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sammy Harkham
title: Forever Is Never
description: A third grader reflects on the miserable year of 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Is Pam Jenoff a Law Professor Moonlighting as a Novelist, or Vice Versa? You Decide
description: The prolific author describes her double life as “messy” and “imperfect.” Nevertheless, she publishes a lot of books.
content: IN BRIEF When Pam Jenoff introduces herself to a new group of students at Rutgers Law School, she doesn’t usually talk about what she’s up to outside the classroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Siblings Are Killed in I-95 Crash in Florida as Suspect Speeds Wrong Way
description: A carjacking suspect fleeing the police drove north in southbound lanes and struck an S.U.V. on Interstate 95 near Daytona Beach.
content: A brother and sister driving back from seeing a display of Christmas lights at Daytona International Speedway in Florida were killed Tuesday night when a man fleeing the police at speeds over 110 m.p.h. drove against traffic on southbound Interstate 95 and struck their S.U.V. head-on, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kari Molvar
title: From Northern California, Farm-Fresh Skin Care
description: A new group of small-batch beauty companies is continuing the region’s storied tradition of organic growing and local sourcing.
content: In certain parts of Northern California, cultivating edible plants — beets, rosemary, kale, lavender — is so central to the lifestyle that, as the Marin County resident Claudia Mata puts it, “It’s a rarity to find someone who isn’t growing their own food or herbs in their backyard.” With its moderate oceanic climate, nutrient-rich soil and free-spirited hippie vibes, the area — which extends roughly from Monterey to Siskiyou County — has long been fertile ground for landmark food and agricultural movements: organic farming in the 1940s, winemaking in the 1960s, farm-to-table cooking in the 1970s. More recently, it has also fostered an influential community of beauty entrepreneurs. Since at least the early aughts, plant-based brands have thrived in the region, offering potent formulas derived from homegrown ingredients and produced in small batches with minimal preservatives. Such principles, coupled with increasing and widespread interest in the kind of holistic living that many Northern Californians have been practicing for decades, have paved the way for today’s larger clean-beauty boom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller, Alicia Parlapiano and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: How We Got Through and What We Missed Most: Lessons From a Pandemic Year
description: Readers across the country told us about their lockdown life. Baking, bourbon and biting nails? Check. But also, resilience and hope.
content: Readers across the country told us about their lockdown life. Baking, bourbon and biting nails? Check. But also, resilience and hope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Opinion
title: Your Dog Had the Best Year Ever
description: The past 10 months have brought us plague, isolation and economic despair. But all that desolation was strangely good news for some people and trends.
content: The past 10 months have brought us plague, isolation and economic despair. But all that desolation was strangely good news for some people and trends.

title: Looking for a Westchester House, but No Gardening Please. Which Did They Choose?
description: Needing more space and a better setup for their growing family, this couple searched some of Westchester’s homeowners’ associations for a house without the headaches. Here’s what they found.

title: Corrections: Dec. 31, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Dec. 31, 2020.
content: An article on Tuesday about a German officer who faces terrorism charges described incorrectly the location of Baustarring, a Bavarian hamlet. It is 250 miles east of Franco A.’s former army base, not 250 miles west.
source.name: The New York Times
